cards.title: Athletics / Great Britain finish fifth at European Team Championships in Russia
cards.rawTitle: Great Britain finish fifth at European Team Championships in Russia

item.title: Great Britain finish fifth at European Team Championships in Russia
item.trailText: Dina Asher-Smith pulled out of the 200m with stomach bug but Rhianwedd Price came third in the 1500m on her debut
item.standFirst:
• Dina Asher-Smith pulls out of 200m with stomach bug
• Rhianwedd Price comes third on debut in 1500m
item.body:
A youthful Great Britain team finished the European Team Championships in fifth place in Cheboksary, Russia.

Britain were unable to add to the four victories they claimed on the first day of competition as they ended the weekend on 291 points, while the hosts took the title with 368.5. Britain’s best hope, Dina Asher-Smith, had to pull out of the 200m with a stomach bug.

The 19-year-old, who a fortnight ago ran the second-fastest 200m by a British woman, of 22.30 seconds, said on Twitter: “So gutted to have to pull out today, haven’t been feeling 100% for a few days and it just got so much worse overnight.”

Instead the performance of the day went to Rhianwedd Price, 20, who battled to third place in the 1500m in 4min 16.59sec. Isobel Pooley in the high jump and Sophie Hitchon in the hammer both achieved world championship qualifying marks.

displayImages.caption: Isobel Pooley, here in Birmingham in June, achieved the World Championship qualifying mark in Russia on Sunday. Photograph: David Davies/PA

cards.title: Rugby league / NRL: five things we learned from round 15
cards.rawTitle: NRL: five things we learned from round 15

item.title: NRL: five things we learned from round 15
item.trailText: The stone killer of Queensland, the bird man of Auckland, no hope for Penrith, Brisbane’s human wall of man-meat, and pep in the Roosters’ step
item.standFirst: The stone killer of Queensland, the bird man of Auckland, no hope for Penrith, Brisbane’s human wall of man-meat, and pep in the Roosters’ step
item.body:
JT: best practice

In terms of a tidbit for “things we learned” it’s as illuminating as “chocolate tastes good” or “Fifa is corrupt” or “James Packer dating Mariah Carey is weirding me out, man”. But after his last-minute field-goal to kill off the Raiders in Canberra, it’s affirmed yet again: when you absolutely, positively need someone to kick a field goal for your life on the death, accept no substitute for Johnathan Thurston. For when everyone else is running about, frothing, leaping, yelling, possessed as if by demons, you want the ball with Thurston. How about him? The man’s a stone killer. The ability to rip off high skill at high speed under pressure both physical – huge men running at you with violent intent – and mental – miss and you don’t win – only a select few human beings are capable of this. And Thurston’s options under the pump are best practice in this National Rugby League. And as a Raiders fan, allow me to add, the bastard.

Bird Man of Auckland

When Shaun Johnson is shredding D-lines with that particular blend of sneaky feet and eyes like a bird’s that can see many directions, all at once, as it’s well known that birds can, it says so in SoundslikesomethingIheardapedia, then rugby league is a happy place. See him against the Gold Coast Titans, frightening lumbering forwards with pace, and a step like a claw hammer tossed down your granddad’s concrete driveway. (Ha.) Johnson’s problem and the Warriors’ problem and by dint the country of New Zealand’s problem, is that next week he could as likely be lost and lonely as a cloud, and his team flogged by Canberra in Auckland. Why is it so? Even enigmatic Professor Julius Sumner Miller couldn’t have told you. Probably.

Playas

When coaches and CEOs and influential men of league gather to talk seriously of the important elements of a premiership-winning season, they talk mostly of men. Of players. And the need the acquire the right ones. Coaches and ancillary staff are important. But players are key. Get the best ones you can, fit and firing at the right time of year, keep them motivated and off the drink (no, Micky Jennings, naughty Micky Jennings) then you give yourself the best possible chance. Look at our premiers the last five years, run through their roster. Best (fit, playing) players equals best results. It’s almost that simple. And it’s for this reason Penrith can’t win the 2015 NRL premiership. Last year they went all-but with an injury list that could’ve lined up in games. But this year they’re bashed up more than an entire series of MASH in which Hawkeye and Radar and Hot Lips Hoolihan and the one who dressed in women’s clothing to get a psyche certificate and get the hell out of Korea have to deal with fresh new casualties, with new stories, and very real human emotion, each week. And with James Segeyaro being carried off to join Brent Kite, Jamal Idris and Matt Moylan, sad to say because they’re plucky and tough but it’s over for Penrith Panthers. Over like tattoos and hipster beards will be soon enough.

Great Wall of Brisbane

The balance of the Brisbane Broncos best XVII has a tasty look about it. Halfback Ben Hunt has skills and smarts. Five-eighth Anthony Milford is hot-footed and fast and has more tricks than Mandrake. And fullback Darius Boyd has been sluicing about behind the backline since 2006, an elite player if not media performer. But now, with the giant shadow of Wayne Bennett looming large like a wraith, say, or an electric blanket the size of Suncorp, the Broncos have mettle. Desperate mettle, the best kind. And they defend like Spartans waiting for the mad ninja hordes of Xerses to attack them through one small gap in a cliff-top. The Broncs are super-fit and go hard, and forwards Adam Blair, Matt Gillett, Josh McGuire, Alex Glenn and Sam Thaiday just go and go. And go again. And again. See them against Melbourne Storm. McGuire made 50 tackles. Gillett made 54 tackles. Hooker Andrew McCullough made 64 tackles. The Storm were missing two of their Big Three but with that weight of possession would have beaten most everyone else. But Brisbane erected a human wall of man-meat. And got the biscuits in Melbourne.

Beasts and bottom feeders

Elsewhere the Dragons and Roosters proved they’re chock-full of hard-acres well prepared for the attritional style of semi-finals rugby league. Both teams’ defensive tenet is hit and be hit, and do it again. That the Chooks did it without the game’s number one beast Jared Waerea-Hargraves will give them plenty of pep in the step heading into September. It’s a month Manly fans would’ve been preparing to holiday in Ballina, say, or Gladstone, even Port Augusta, just a few weeks ago. But the Sea Eagles looked hard and fast at Brookvale Friday night, and if they can keep their star halves fit and on the field, they’re … well. They’re still last. But their odds to win the premiership are now 33-1, while their fellow bottom dwellers the Titans, Tigers, Eels and Knights are 100-1 and worse. And lastly Cronulla beat Newcastle by two points, and Luke Lewis scored a fine try in which he touched the ball twice in the movement and ran like the winger he was in 1983. And good luck to him.

displayImages.credit: Lukas Coch/AAP
displayImages.altText: Johnathan Thurston was again the hero for the Cowboys against the Raiders at GIO Stadium in Canberra.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Lukas Coch/AAP

cards.title: Snooker / Ronnie O’Sullivan claims he was offered money to throw a snooker match
cards.rawTitle: Ronnie O’Sullivan claims he was offered money to throw a snooker match

item.title: Ronnie O’Sullivan claims he was offered money to throw a snooker match
item.trailText: Ronnie O’Sullivan has claimed he was offered money to throw a snooker match but turned it down as the risk was not worth taking
item.standFirst:
• Five-times world champion says the risk is not worth taking
• Stephen Lee’s 12-year ban has scared a lot of players, he adds
item.body:
Ronnie O’Sullivan, the five-times world snooker champion, has said he was offered money to throw a match but declined.

Speaking on The Clare Balding Show, which will air on BT Sport and BBC Two this week, O’Sullivan claimed other players did accept bribes in the past but said he believed the problem had been eradicated after Stephen Lee was banned for match-fixing.

O’Sullivan said: “I was offered money once to throw a game but I couldn’t do it. It’s your sport, you love your sport. They smell it anyway. The risk is just not worth taking and I couldn’t live with myself if I got involved in that.”

In 2012 Lee was suspended on match-fixing charges and the former world No5 was subsequently handed a 12-year ban.

Related: Stephen Lee banned from snooker for 12 years for seven match-fixing charges

“I don’t think it’ll go on in snooker any more because they really made an example of Stephen Lee,” O’Sullivan added. “They banned him for 12 years and I think a lot of the guys that were at it, they’re thinking they wouldn’t be able to play snooker ever again.

“So I think it’s been stamped out of snooker now and if anyone was to do it, they know what the consequences are.”

Three weeks ago, the Irish amateur John Sutton was banned for six years after the sport’s world governing body found him guilty of match-fixing and misusing inside information.

The World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association said Sutton’s offences related to suspicious betting on his match against Scotland’s Jamie Burnett in the qualifying stages of the International Championship.

cards.title: US sports / ‘42 is the new 32’: Oscar De La Hoya considering surprise comeback
cards.rawTitle: ‘42 is the new 32’: Oscar De La Hoya considering surprise comeback

item.title: ‘42 is the new 32’: Oscar De La Hoya considering surprise comeback
item.trailText: Oscar De La Hoya says there is a “50-50” chance that he could make a surprise boxing comeback, more than six years since announcing his retirement
item.standFirst:
• ‘It’s got to be worth my while but this is very serious’
• De La Hoya targets Floyd Mayweather or Gennady Golovkin
item.body:
Oscar De La Hoya says the is very serious about making a surprise boxing comeback, more than six years since announcing his retirement.

De La Hoya, whose last bout was a defeat to Manny Pacquiao in December 2008, last week ruled out a return after Floyd Mayweather had hinted the six-weight world champion was on the verge of boxing again.

However, the 42-year-old, who has been concentrating on his promotional company Golden Boy since retiring, told ESPN that he is in “the shape of his and life” and weighing up the possibility of making a comeback.

“It’s got to be worth my while but this is very serious,” De La Hoya said. “I have to make sure I am fighting the very best. I don’t have to come back for financial reasons or the lights or the glamour. The only reason I would come back is because I miss the competition of fighting the very best.

“I feel amazing. In my life right now, I have so much motivation. I am so hungry and so determined. My plan is long term with Golden Boy, with me personally, my family, my business. I am young, I am healthy and I feel great. 42 is the new 32.”

After losing to Mayweather on a split decision in May 2007, De La Hoya revealed last week that a rematch clause with his unbeaten compatriot had already expired. But with Mayweather yet to announce his next opponent following his victory over Pacquiao, De La Hoya indicated that he would only be interested in returning to fight his old adversary or reigning WBA and IBO middleweight champion Gennady Golovkin.

“I just feel good and when I walk the streets, everyone tells me, ‘You have to fight Floyd again, you have to fight GGG. You can do it, you can do it’,” he said.

“I just feel great physically. I’ve been taking care of myself. I’ve been doing the Bernard Hopkins lifestyle. You can turn the clock back to a certain time.

“I want to fight one of them because they are the best and I always fought the best. That’s what boxing is all about - fighting the best.”

De La Hoya, who has a history of drug and alcohol abuse, has had two spells in rehab since retiring. But he insisted that he dreams of emulating Sugar Ray Leonard, who returned to the sport after nearly three years out to beat reigning middleweight champion Marvin Hagler in 1987.

“Right now I feel the best I have felt in my life physically, emotionally, mentally because I haven’t touched alcohol for I don’t know how long. I’m training. I feel great. But it has to be worth my while,” said De La Hoya.

“Would I do it? I don’t know but I wake up every morning thinking that I can. I think about Sugar Ray Leonard and Marvin Hagler. If [Leonard] could do it, why can’t I? We both come from similar situations. We are both hungry for the competition, we’re both ambitious. So you never know. At the same time, I wish time flies by so I don’t have to come back.”

cards.title: Australia sport / Former rugby union star Norm Berryman dies of heart attack at 42
cards.rawTitle: Former rugby union star Norm Berryman dies of heart attack at 42

item.title: Former rugby union star Norm Berryman dies of heart attack at 42
item.trailText: Former All Blacks captain Tana Umaga has led the tributes for popular former rugby union star Norm Berryman, who has died at the age of 42
item.standFirst:
• Tributes flow for flamboyant former player
  • ‘A life lost too young,’ says Tana Umaga
item.body:
Former All Blacks captain Tana Umaga has led the tributes for popular former rugby union star Norm Berryman, who has died at the age of 42. Berryman died on Tuesday of a heart attack in Australia, where he has been based for several years.

A father of six, he had recently worked as a forklift driver in Perth, where he had also played club rugby. Umaga and others expressed shock and sadness at the passing of Berryman, who will be remembered for a flamboyant attacking style and laid-back approach off the field.

A decade-long career through the 1990s included three seasons with the Crusaders, where he won three Super Rugby titles from 1998-2000. He also represented the Chiefs and Blues. Berryman’s lone Test appearance was off the reserves bench in a 24-23 loss to South Africa in 1998.

“He always had a big smile,” Umaga said. “He loved life, loved his family, he’ll be a big loss. It’s a life lost too young.”

Umaga was constantly amazed by Berryman’s ability to scythe through defences, belying a physique which was wider of girth than most of his peers, and admits he was embarrassed more than once defensively when the pair locked horns at provincial and Super Rugby level.

“There were probably a few times where he beat me on the outside, the inside, upside-down, I’m not too sure. He was that good with his footwork. He had amazing skills for a big man.”

“Stormin” Norman Berryman, as many supporters knew him, represented New Zealand Maori across an 11-year span and finished his playing career with short stints at French clubs Castres and Bourgoin.

Berryman’s death follows that of another recent former All Black, Jerry Collins, who died in a car accident in France this month. Collins’s wife was also killed and their baby daughter remains on life support.

displayImages.credit: Dave Rogers/Getty Images Sport
displayImages.altText: Norm Berryman
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Dave Rogers/Getty Images Sport

cards.title: Olympic Games 2016 / GB women one win from securing Olympic spot after sinking South Africa
cards.rawTitle: GB women one win from securing Olympic spot after sinking South Africa

item.title: GB women one win from securing Olympic spot after sinking South Africa
item.trailText: Alex Danson hailed a ‘really professional performance’ by Great Britain after their 2-0 win over South Africa
item.standFirst:
• Reading striker Alex Danson gives Great Britain 12th-minute lead
• Ireland suffer 4-3 World League shootout defeat by China
item.body:
Great Britain’s women are one win away from Olympic qualification after a fifth successive victory at the World League tournament in Valencia.

Two goals in the opening 14 minutes were enough to beat South Africa 2-0. The victory took them into the World League final in Argentina in December but, more importantly, a top-three finish in this tournament will guarantee a spot at the Rio 2016 Games.

The Reading striker Alex Danson scored her third goal of the competition with a clever spin and shot in the 12th minute and then her club-mate Kate Richardson-Walsh’s deflected penalty corner flew in off the underside of the crossbar.

“We are absolutely delighted. It was a really professional performance by the team,” Danson said. “I think the work we do back home puts us in a good position here; fitness is a key thing and we still have a lot left in the legs.”

Great Britain will face the winners of Germany against Spain in Saturday’s semi-final.

Ireland’s hopes of securing automatic Olympic qualification for the first time were cruelly dashed in a 4-3 shootout defeat by China.

Having conceded an early goal, Ireland deservedly equalised through Chloe Watkins with 18 minutes to go and they were denied a winner when Megan Frazer’s goal was disallowed after an umpire’s video referral.

Ayeisha McFerran was put in goal for the shootout and made two saves but, when Nicola Evans missed the chance to win on the last of the five regulation attempts they lost out in the second round of sudden death.

Ireland’s diminishing hopes of reaching Brazil next year rest with them finishing fifth and hoping results at other qualifying competitions later this year go their way.

item.title: Volvo Ocean Race: stage 9
item.trailText: The best pictures from the ninth and final leg of the 2014-15 Volvo Ocean Race, from Lorient in France to Gothenburg in Sweden
item.standFirst:
The best pictures from the ninth and final leg of the 2014-15 Volvo Ocean Race, from L’Orient in France to Gothenburg in Sweden, via a 24 hour pit stop in The Hague. The race covers 39,379 nautical miles and visits 11 ports in 11 countries over nine months. The overall winners were Abu Dhabi Ocean Racing, finishing 24 minutes ahead of second-placed Team Brunel.

• More of the best images from the Volvo Ocean Race

snap.title: Volvo Ocean Race: stage 9 – in pictures

image.caption: The teams start from L’Orient, France Photograph: Ainhoa Sanchez/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Ainhoa Sanchez/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.altText: The teams start from L’Orient, France
image.cleanCaption: The teams start from L’Orient, France
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Ainhoa Sanchez/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images

image.caption: A jumper leaves the Dongfeng Race Team during the start from L’Orient Photograph: Ainhoa Sanchez/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Ainhoa Sanchez/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.altText: A jumper leaves the Dongfeng Race Team during the start from L’Orient
image.cleanCaption: A jumper leaves the Dongfeng Race Team during the start from L’Orient
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Ainhoa Sanchez/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images

image.caption: The fleet head to The Hague, then Gothenburg Photograph: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.altText: The fleet head to The Hague, then Gothenburg
image.cleanCaption: The fleet head to The Hague, then Gothenburg
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images

image.caption: After a quick start out of L’Orient and a ‘tour de France’ through the Bay of Quiberon, the fleet then begins the 600 mile trek up the coast, around Brest, and into the Channel Photograph: Amory Ross/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Amory Ross/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.altText: After a quick start out of L’Orient and a ‘tour de France’ through the Bay of Quiberon, the fleet then begins the 600 mile trek up the coast, around Brest, and into the Channel
image.cleanCaption: After a quick start out of L’Orient and a ‘tour de France’ through the Bay of Quiberon, the fleet then begins the 600 mile trek up the coast, around Brest, and into the Channel
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Amory Ross/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images

image.caption: Onboard Team Alvimedica. Free from the Bay of Biscay the fleet rounds Brest on the way to the Channel, all within close proximity of one another. Will Oxley looks at the on-deck nav screen while navigating the busy French coastline Photograph: Amory Ross/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Amory Ross/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.altText: Onboard Team Alvimedica. Free from the Bay of Biscay the fleet rounds Brest on the way to the English Channel, all within close proximity. Will Oxley looks at the on-deck nav screen while navigating the busy French coastline
image.cleanCaption: Onboard Team Alvimedica. Free from the Bay of Biscay the fleet rounds Brest on the way to the Channel, all within close proximity of one another. Will Oxley looks at the on-deck nav screen while navigating the busy French coastline
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Amory Ross/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images

image.caption: Jens Dolmer and Louis Balcaen try and make up time after Team Brunel dropped from 1st to 7th within one hour due to a breakdown caused by weed on the keel, near the coast of Bretagne Photograph: Stefan Coppers/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Stefan Coppers/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.altText: Jens Dolmer and Louis Balcaen try and make up time after Team Brunel dropped from 1st to 7th within one hour due to a breakdown caused by weed on the keel, near the coast of Bretagne
